SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, tired, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He has been involved in home renovation projects and has had difficulty maintaining a healthy diet due to the construction in his kitchen. He denies fever, chills, and cough but endorses bloating and shortness of breath during exertion. He also reports occasional chest cramps that resolve within an hour.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Positive for bloating and chest cramps. Denies chest pain.
• Respiratory: Positive for shortness of breath during exertion. Denies cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Lungs: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Shows fluid in the lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Reduced pumping function at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient to weigh themselves daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient to continue recording blood pressures at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was on a ladder changing a light bulb yesterday and stumbled, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help. She denies any other injuries. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a nose job. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with valgus stress and knee flexion. Normal sensation is present. No calf pain or tenderness.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus strain.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a 2-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning. He heard a pop in his lower back and had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. The pain has been persistent and stiff since then. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat without significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon, which then resolved.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not maintaining a consistent diet recently. He has been taking his medications as prescribed.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He has been taking his medication as prescribed.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, he experiences occasional aggravation in his knee, but overall it has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever or chills.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies joint pain or swelling.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in right toes, resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment and no fracture present.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and strengthening exercises.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been compliant with medications but admits to recent dietary inconsistencies. His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings have been running on the high side. The patient is compliant with medications but may need an adjustment.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been managing his knee pain well and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been on Prozac and reports no recent incidents, feeling well-managed and maintained. He has been taking Norvasc for hypertension but admits to occasionally forgetting to take it on weekends. He had a lobectomy a couple of years ago and reports no significant issues with shortness of breath, except during high pollen season and when running in humid conditions.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath with exertion during running.
• Respiratory: Denies cough or wheezing.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, well-managed with medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension. He presents for his annual exam.

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: Well-managed with Prozac.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill ordered.

Prior Lobectomy.
• Medical Reasoning: No significant issues with shortness of breath, exercising regularly.
• Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure controlled, despite occasional missed doses on weekends.
• Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right middle finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Hill is a 41-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right middle finger pain after she was rear-ended in a motor vehicle accident 5 days ago. She has no other injuries.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Digoxin

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Atrial Fibrillation

EXAM:

Examination of the right middle finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right middle finger, 3 views obtained on today's visit shows a distal phalanx fracture.

IMPRESSION:

Right middle finger distal phalanx fracture.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend a prescription for Tramadol 50 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain, dispense 8. She is provided a finger splint and will return in 2 weeks for a follow-up x-ray. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia since the age of 13. She recently attempted to donate blood in December but was told she was anemic. She reports feeling fatigued, feverish with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also experiences cold intolerance and worsening anxiety and depression. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, fever, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.
• Psychiatric: Endorses worsening anxiety and depression.

MEDICATIONS

• Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
• Over-the-counter Vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Normal.
• Respiratory: Normal.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen non-tender, no significant findings.
• Musculoskeletal: Normal.
• Neurological: Normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia since the age of 13, presenting with fatigue, fever, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, cold intolerance, and worsening anxiety and depression.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a long-standing history of anemia. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate and Vitamin B12 supplements. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.
• Additional Testing: Schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer the patient to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to take her iron pills with orange juice to improve iron absorption. Continue this for 8-12 weeks and then reassess blood work.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. He has no history of headaches and his past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, coagulation, and CRP, were normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago and worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, including fever, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has noticed recently that he seems to be bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer.
Marital status: Married for 25 years.
Recently bought a small house.
No history of alcohol, smoking, or recreational drug use.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

RESULTS

MRI brain with contrast (3/4/21): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
2. Refer the patient to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to assess peripheral vision before and after surgery.
3. Schedule surgery with the surgery scheduler, Deborah.
4. Monitor the patient's vision and headaches post-surgery.

The patient is informed of the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia. He understands the need for surgery and agrees to proceed.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill, a 52-year-old female, presents for a follow-up after an ER visit for chest pain in early October 2020. The patient experienced chest pain for four days, which resolved after the ER visit. She reports that the pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and felt like a sharp pain. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during the episode, which has since resolved. The patient denies any heartburn or indigestion at the time but is unsure what heartburn feels like. The pain was worse with eating. She has no family history of GI problems and has had her gallbladder removed several years ago.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Lower abdomen: No pain or tenderness upon palpation.
• Upper abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 52-year-old female who presents for follow-up after an ER visit for chest pain. The ER ruled out heart issues with EKG and blood tests. Possible etiologies for her chest pain include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient mentioned a stressful job transition around the time of the episode, which may have contributed to her symptoms.

Given that the patient has been asymptomatic for three months, we discussed the options of performing an EGD or upper endoscopy to evaluate her esophagus and stomach versus monitoring for any additional symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. She will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, gastroesophageal reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently receiving feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. The patient has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned that individuals with Smith-Magenis Syndrome may have kidney anomalies. The family is here today for a kidney evaluation.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills, or weight loss.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: No recent ear infections or sore throat.
• Cardiovascular: No known heart issues.
• Respiratory: No cough or shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: History of gastroesophageal reflux.
• Genitourinary: 8-10 wet diapers per day, no known issues with urinary tract.
• Musculoskeletal: Developmental delays, mild hypotonia in lower extremities.
• Neurological: No seizures or other neurological issues.
• Endocrine: No known endocrine issues.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Extremities: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function. Given the potential for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract associated with this syndrome, we will obtain a screening kidney ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, a 35-year-old female, presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right wrist pain. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms outstretched. She reports that her right wrist became swollen and painful immediately after the fall. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ACE wrap, and taking ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists. The patient denies any previous injuries to this arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain.
Neurological: Reports mild tingling in fingers, but no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20 bpm
Temp: 97.2°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower edema, palpable pulses in lower legs.
Upper extremities: Normal range of movement in shoulders and left wrist. Right wrist exhibits pain on flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. Patient able to make a fist, but not tightly. Obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation of the right wrist. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have discussed with the patient her current symptoms and diagnosis. I have recommended conservative treatment initially, including a wrist brace for six weeks. The patient will undergo surgery to repair the fracture, followed by an overnight stay in the hospital. Post-surgery, the patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management and will begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery. The patient will return for a follow-up appointment in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the office if her pain worsens or if she experiences any complications.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping and falling on his property a week ago, resulting in right knee pain and swelling. Pain is worse with flexion and extension of the knee.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg Lisinopril.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Right knee with pain to palpation on the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema, and effusion.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Treatment: Ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Knee brace for support. Ice therapy for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Advised to elevate and rest the leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of dietary changes, including reducing sodium intake. Referral to nutritionist for further guidance.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects that the pain may be related to this activity. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens when pressure is applied, such as when lying on the shoulder. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a 91-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of left knee pain. The pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, and is described as the whole kneecap feeling unstable. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any pain medications as the pain does not last long. The knee pain has not significantly interfered with her daily activities, but she is concerned about an upcoming trip where she will be doing a lot of walking and line dancing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension and diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS

Farxiga, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2°F, pulse 72, respirations 16, blood pressure 122/70.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For left knee pain, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and make any necessary adjustments to metformin dosage.

The patient will be scheduled for an echocardiogram, and the nurse will assist with setting up the appointment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sore throat and cough.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports having a good support system, including family members and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
HENT: Reports sore throat and dry cough.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: Unremarkable.

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat
- Examination of Throat: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy noted.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles noted bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination of Chest: Erythema on the anterior side of the left chest, likely related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess tumor response and potential for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles on lung exam are likely due to radiation-induced inflammation.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat may be related to radiation-induced inflammation in the esophagus.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports frequent colds in the wintertime, which tend to linger. Patient's family owns a donut shop. Patient denies any family history of immune deficiencies.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes, recently started on metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal infections or diarrhea.

VITALS

No fever or concerning vitals.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Neck
- Examination: No lymphadenopathy.

Abdominal
- Examination: Soft, non-tender.

RESULTS

Lab work consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work shows low IgA levels, which can be associated with frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections. However, the patient does not seem to have significant issues with infections.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The nature of the diagnosis was discussed with the patient. I explained that IgA deficiency is a common immunodeficiency and that many people live their entire lives without knowing they have it. I advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control, as well as any changes in their abdominal tract. The patient was also advised to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.
- Medical Treatment: Additional blood work will be ordered to check other antibodies. No other significant interventions are recommended at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of his elbow and radiates slightly into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The patient has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we had a discussion in regards to his current symptoms. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow, wear a sling while awake, apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day, and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is also advised to refrain from pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to evaluate the patient's progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent hospitalization for congestive heart failure.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during physical activity.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: Not reported
Heart Rate: Not reported
Oxygen Saturation: Not reported

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Patient advised to weigh themselves daily and call if they gain 3 pounds in 2 days.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of taking medications consistently and monitoring diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney stones.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of kidney stones. The patient was referred from his primary care physician. He has been experiencing sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. The patient reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for the pain, but it has not been effective. The patient has a history of kidney stones and has been able to pass them in the past. His father also had kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Urinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no evidence of rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

We reviewed the patient's CT results in detail today. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have prescribed the patient oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain. He may continue to take Tylenol between the oxycodone doses for any breakthrough pain. The patient will be given a strainer to use when he urinates until the stone passes. I have also recommended that we obtain a BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, we will discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy. The patient is advised to contact me if he experiences worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 79-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for about six weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a pair of tight shoes. The ulcer started as a blister and has since become unroofed with thick, soft, mushy skin and yellow drainage. The patient has been on antibiotics for six days, and initially experienced some improvement, but now reports the wound has turned black around the edges and he is experiencing calf cramping. He also reports a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is hot to touch. The patient has a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, and his blood sugars have been trending higher in the past few weeks.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently went on a hike before the ulcer developed. He wears diabetic shoes and inserts, which he changes every three to four months.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever of 99.7 and chills before starting antibiotics.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports coughing and difficulty catching breath when walking around the house.
Skin: Reports non-healing right foot ulcer with black edges and red streak up the calf.
Neurological: No numbness or tingling reported.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No abnormalities noted.
RESPIRATORY: No abnormalities noted.
NECK: No abnormalities noted.
MSK: Examination of the right foot reveals a 2 x 2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler. No pain on palpation of the affected area.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes
3. Possible infection

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed the following plan:

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement of the wound in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture of the wound and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on culture results.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the patient's calf closely and schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
5. Recommend the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to ensure proper management of his diabetes and blood sugar levels.

The patient understands the plan and has no further questions or concerns at this time.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors and recently went hunting. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been burning and causing discomfort. He has not experienced fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and having a headache since the tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, Diabetes

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain in joints, no new joint pain since tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Temperature: 98.4 F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite with concern for Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a bull's-eye rash over the right knee and reports feeling unwell since the tick bite.
- Medical Treatment: Start Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for three weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm Lyme disease diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily. Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed or if symptoms worsen.
